title: The Small Grains Foundry
text:
Redesigning Small Grains for Global Health and Resilience
Most modern crops are like race cars: they go fast (high yield) but only with perfect conditions, expensive fuel (fertilizer), and lots of maintenance (water).
We do things differently. At the Small Grains Foundry, we design bread wheat, durum wheat, barley, oat, and triticale that are tough by nature. We develop grains that grow strong in real-world fields with less water and fertilizer, while producing healthier food for your table every day.











Note

title: The Small Grains Foundry
text:
Research highlights


Grains for Health
(The Nutrition Project)
We believe bread should be food for a healthier life. We have developed special ‘Elite’ seeds that are nearly ready for farmers to plant. These include a ‘gut-friendly’ wheat with reduced immunogenicity, a high-fiber wheat to help prevent disease, and our recently released variety that is naturally packed with extra pro-Vitamin A.


Lasting Protection
(The Stripe Rust Project)
Crop diseases act like ‘hackers’ that are always trying to break into the plant. Our lab is a key watchdog for the U.S., which means we often see new stripe rust races early. Instead of a quick fix that stops working after several years, we study how groups of genes work together to give the plant a durable ‘firewall’ against disease.


Better Plant Design
(The Low-Input Project)
We are rethinking how crops grow so they do not need too much fertilizer and extra water. By using specific genes that change plant architecture, we build crops that stay short and strong while growing deeper roots. This helps farmers get a good harvest even during a drought, and it protects the environment by using fewer inputs.


Digging for Secrets
(The Evo-Mining Project)
Modern farming has focused so much on high yields that it accidentally lost traits that help plants survive heat and stress. We go ‘mining’ in older varieties to find these lost survival secrets. We study the complex DNA of wheat to unlock old ways of staying resilient that have not been seen in modern fields for centuries.

title: The Small Grains Foundry
text:
Why Join the Foundry?
We are Field-First. We do not just simulate stress on a computer; we solve it where it happens. You will work in the real-world heat and drought conditions of California, because that is where true resilience is proven.
Master the Modern Breeding Toolkit. We train students to be leaders in both industry and academia. You will not just learn one skill; you will master the entire pipeline from lab to harvest:

The Tech: Learn genetic mapping, big data analysis, and high-tech phenotyping (using sensors to measure plant growth).
The Science: Connect molecular and quantitative genetics and evolutionary theory to practical breeding to unlock survival traits in the wheat genome.
The Grit: Gain hands-on experience managing your own field trials—a skill highly valued by top agricultural companies and elite research universities.

The Goal: To graduate as a scientist who uses advanced tools to solve real-world problems.

title: Research
text: We integrate multi-environment field trials, comparative genomics, and high-throughput phenomics to understand and improve stability in yield, quality, and stress response in small grains.

title: Research
text:
Theme 1 — Bio-Design for Human Nutrition
Engineering Grain for Metabolic Health
Food security is a function of nutrient density, not just caloric volume. We treat nutritional quality as a primary breeding objective rather than a secondary trait. Our research focuses on:

Gut Health & Glycemic Index: Leveraging QTLs and genes for arabinoxylan and high-amylose content to increase dietary fiber.
Immunogenicity: Using gliadin deletions to reduce gluten-related sensitivity while maintaining or enhancing dough processing strength.
Micronutrient Density: Deploying biofortification strategies, such as our recently released high-beta-carotene wheat varieties.

title: Research
text:
Theme 2 — Translating Discoveries into Varieties
Modern Tools, Real-world Impact
Basic discovery must bridge the gap to deployment. We operate efficient breeding pipelines that integrate:

Precision Tools: Genomic selection, speed breeding, and CRISPR-informed trait introgression.
Scalable Phenomics: High-throughput field phenotyping to capture real-time data on plant development.
Impact: This integrated approach allows us to move efficiently from genetic insight to breeder seed release.

title: Research
text:
Theme 3 — Epistasis & Trait Stability
Stripe Rust as a Model for Complex Gene Interactions
A persistent challenge in crop improvement is genetic background effects—why a gene works in one variety but fails in another. We use stripe rust as a biological tool to study this problem in real field environments. By shifting focus from single R-genes to gene interaction networks, we are developing a framework for durable disease resistance that remains stable across diverse environments.

title: Research
text:
Theme 4 — Beyond the Green Revolution
Optimizing Performance for Low-Input Environments
The Green Revolution increased yield by relying on high inputs such as fertilizer and irrigation. However, these systems are increasingly costly and unsustainable. Our program addresses this limitation by studying novel semidwarfing genes that reshape plant architecture while preserving early vigor, biomass, and grain filling under drought and nitrogen limitation. This work aims to develop new crop designs that maintain strong yield and stability under real-world farming conditions.

title: Research
text:
Theme 5 — Evo-Mining & Polyploid Dynamics
Unlock the Adaptive Potential of the Wheat Genome
Modern breeding has increased yields but has narrowed crops’ ability to adapt to environmental stress. Our research asks a fundamental evolutionary question: how does polyploid genome structure interact with historical selection to shape long-term adaptation? Using wheat as a modern polyploid crop, we compare landraces, modern cultivars, and regionally distinct lineages in multi-environment field trials. This work integrates evolution, polyploid biology, and field performance to identify pathways for rebuilding resilience in modern crops.

title: Collaboration
text:
The Small Grain Foundry is built for partnership, offering a unique ‘field-first’ infrastructure that bridges high-level genomics with large-scale phenotypic reality.
Whether you are a biotechnologist looking to validate gene function in elite germplasm, a computational biologist seeking high-quality field data to refine predictive models, or a private-sector partner aiming to deploy resilient, nutrient-dense varieties, we invite you to join our mission. By combining our strengths in evo-mining, stripe rust diagnostics, and nutritional bio-design, we can accelerate the transition from genetic discovery to real-world agricultural impact.

title: Publications
text:
Durum wheat with Yr78 and common wheat with Yr78 and Yr36 in coupling show enhanced stripe rust resistance (2025) Stripe rust resistance improved by combining key loci in wheat backgrounds.
Introgression of stem rust resistance gene Sr68 from Thinopyrum junceum into wheat (2025) Transfers durable stem rust resistance from wild relatives into wheat germplasm.
Pan-genome and haplotype map of cassava cultivars and wild ancestors provide insights into its adaptive evolution and domestication (2025) We obtained near complete telomere-to-telomere genome assemblies and their haplotype forms for the cultivar AM560, the wild ancestors FLA4047 and W14, constructed a graphic pan-genome of 30 representatives with a size of 1.15 Gb, and built a clarified evolutionary tree of 486 accessions.
Genetic mapping and validation of QTL for whitefly resistance in cassava (Manihot esculenta Crantz) (2025) We identified QTL on chromosomes 1, 2, 5, 6, 8, 9, and 14, with a stable and highly significant QTL on chromosome 8 (MeF2WFly8.1), explaining 35.44% of the phenotypic variation.
Assessing realized genetic gains in biofortified cassava breeding for over a decade: Enhanced nutritional value and agronomic performance (2024) We present realized genetic gains in biofortified cassava by analyzing the data from replicated multilocation breeding yield trials at the target population of environments spanning a 10-year period (2013–2022).
Towards transforming cassava breeding: harnessing inbred-parent-based hybrid breeding strategies (2024) We propose an innovative approach – inbred-parent-based hybrid cassava breeding, aiming to transform cassava breeding by implementing backcrossing-based trait introgression, effectively purging deleterious mutations, and systematically exploring and utilizing heterosis.
